sections.title: Prove Your Idea Deserves Liftoff
sections.subtitle: Stress-test the problem, audience, and solution before you invest serious time or money

sections.title: What You'll Build
items: A crystal-clear problem statement backed by real-world evidence
A target customer profile with pains, needs, and purchasing triggers
A simple validation plan leveraging interviews, forums, and waitlists
An action scorecard that decides pivot, pursue, or pause

sections.title: Start With the Pain, Not the Product
sections.content: Great companies solve painful problems. Identify the job customers need done and the workaround they currently tolerate. Document costs (money, time, frustration) so you can quantify why solving it matters.

points.title: Urgency
points.description: Is the problem frequent or expensive enough that customers actively seek solutions?

points.title: Budget
points.description: Have customers already paid for alternatives? Prior spending indicates willingness to pay.

points.title: Access
points.description: Can you reach customers through communities, ads, or partnerships without unsustainable costs?

sections.title: Quantify Interest Early
sections.content: A 20% conversion rate from landing page visits to waitlist sign-ups is a solid benchmark for consumer ideas. Iterate until you hit a metric that proves traction.

sections.title: Validation Sprint
steps: Write a one-sentence problem statement and share it with three potential customers for feedback.
Host five discovery calls focused on pain points, not pitching your solution.
Draft a simple value proposition and landing page using no-code tools.
Drive targeted traffic (forums, niche communities, small ad spend) and measure sign-up interest.
Score results using a pursue/pause/pivot matrix and document your next move.

sections.title: Avoid Confirmation Bias
sections.content: Ask open-ended questions and let interviewees talk. The more they reveal unprompted, the more authentic your insights.
